title: Boris Johnson blames Iran for Saudi oil attack
text:
Johnson said he is set to hold talks with Iranian President Hassan Rouhani on Tuesday | Ben Stansall/AFP via Getty Images Boris Johnson blames Iran for Saudi oil attack UK PM says London would ‘consider’ any requests for military assistance from Saudi Arabia and the US.

NEW YORK — Boris Johnson has blamed Iran for the attack on Saudi Arabian oil facilities that reignited tensions in the Gulf.

"I can tell you that the U.K. is attributing responsibility with a very high degree of probability to Iran for the Aramco attacks," the U.K. PM said. Downing Street said the strikes were conducted using drones and cruise missiles.

As he jetted across the Atlantic to the United Nations General Assembly in New York, Johnson also left the door open to sending troops to Saudi Arabia to help defend its facilities — although he insisted the U.K. wants to “de-escalate tensions in the Gulf region.”

“We will consider in what way we could be useful if asked — depending on what the exact plan is,” he said, adding the U.K. would consider any requests for help from Saudi Arabia and the U.S.

U.S. President Donald Trump has already laid the blame for the attacks on Iran and is sending troops to assist Riyadh with air and missile defense.

Johnson said he is set to hold talks with Iranian President Hassan Rouhani on Tuesday, on the fringes of the U.N. summit. The meeting will come just hours after face-to-face talks with Trump.

He also told journalists on the RAF Voyager plane that hammering out an international response to the attack would be a core focus of his efforts at the global summit.

“Everybody wants to try to do what they can to bring the world together in response to what happened in Saudi Arabia in our management of Iran,” he said.

“The difficulty is how do we organize an appropriate response … We’ll be working with our American friends and our European friends to construct a response that tries to de-escalate tensions in the Gulf region.”

He will also discuss the response today with German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron.

A senior U.K. government official said a claim by Houthi rebels in Yemen that they were behind the Aramco attack was “implausible.”

“Imagery from the site of the attack shows the remnants of Iranian-made land-attack cruise missiles and the scale of sophistication and range of the attack is inconsistent with the Houthis’ capability,” the official said.

They added: “The sophistication points very firmly to Iranian involvement. It’s implausible that it wouldn’t have been authorized by the Iranian regime.”
description: UK PM says London would ‘consider’ any requests for military assistance from Saudi Arabia and the US.
